qas.question: Which two important psychologists did Popper view as advancing non-scientific theories?
Whose recent breakthrough in physics did Popper view as paradigmatic science?
What quality of the theory of relativity did Popper believe made it proper science?
What did Popper think psychoanalytic theory shared more feature with than real science ?
What could you not do to psychoanalytic theory that Popper believed crucial in genuine science?
When did Adler set off a revolution in the field of physics?
What did Freud think Einstein's theory was?
When did Popper's experiments confirm light is deflected towards solid bodies?
Who though psychoanalytic theories had more in common with genuine science than myths?
What field did Einstein set off a revolution in during the late 20th century?

context: <b8_0>Popper<b8_0/> puzzled over the stark contrast between the non-scientific character of <a0_0>Freud and Adler<a0_0/>'s theories in the field of psychology and the revolution set off by <a1_0>Einstein<a1_0/>'s theory of relativity in <b9_0>physics<b9_0/> in the <b5_0>early 20th century<b5_0/>. Popper thought that Einstein's theory, as a theory properly grounded in scientific thought and method, was <b6_0>highly "<a2_0>risky<a2_0/>"<b6_0/>, in the sense that it was possible to deduce consequences from it which were, in the light of the then-dominant Newtonian physics, highly improbable (e.g., that light is deflected towards solid bodies—confirmed by Eddington's experiments in <b7_0>1919<b7_0/>), and which would, if they turned out to be false, <a4_0>falsify<a4_0/> the whole theory. In contrast, nothing could, even in principle, falsify psychoanalytic theories. He thus came to the conclusion that psychoanalytic theories had more in common with <a3_0>primitive myths<a3_0/> than with genuine science.
